 Strict Constructionism is the Cliff Notes version of law. You cannot have strict constructionism and avoid absurd results and miscarriages of justice.
 
 Read the First, Fourth, Fifth and Sixth amendments. These are all privacy rights, depending on the context. Do you really think the 4th amendment isn't about privacy, just because it's 18th century authors didn't use a particular word?

 I have news for you Steve, there were abortions before Roe v. Wade. Abortion in fact, is older than history, it has been around as long as humanity has been having families. Before people lived in the highly developed community's they live in nowadays, they lived of the land, and ate what they could find. As a result they knew how the resources in their environment affected their bodies, they knew what gave them the energy they needed, and they knew what was poison, and you better believe they knew what leaves or roots they had to eat to educe a miscarriage. The abortions that take place in clinics in modern times are no more than scientific developments on this entirely natural human practice made for the sake of safty. Abortion and other forms of abandonment are and always have been a harsh and difficult part of life. Roe v. Wade did nothing more than protect the rights and the privacy of the unfortunate women who have to deal with this difficult reality in their own lives.
 
 It was a ruling that protected them from people like you who causally dismiss this part of nature as "immoral" or "wrong" because you don't have to deal with the consequences of that dismissal.
